This is to remind you all that the session of Career Conclave organised by CDC, on preparation for Machine Learning/Data Analytics profiles, is scheduled to be held at Kalidas Auditorium at 6:00pm today.

Anyone who is remotely interested in ML/DA companies should definitely attend this session, especially those in their pre-final or pre-internship year. Over 30% UG students were placed in a Data Science Profile this year. At least 25% profiles open for any given department were Data Science profiles. Given the number of opportunities for everyone, irrespective of the department, we highly recommend that you attend the session even if you are remotely interested in this area.

As mentioned previously, the session will be hosted by Kumar Krishna Agarwal (Goldman Sachs and Xerox Research), Bhupendra Bule (Quantiphi), Manish Goyal (SAP Labs) and Ashish Kumar (Cognizant).

We had successfully conducted an introductory workshop on GSoC wherein we had invited speakers who were selected as students as well as mentors in GSoC. They shared their experiences, benefits, tips and advice on how to participate in the open source culture! Thanks to all of the speakers (Pranit Bauva, Himanshu Mishra, Avijit Ghosh, Nishant Nikhil, Sampad Saha, Anchit Navelkar, Shivam Vats, Ayush Pandey, Harsh Gupta, Pranay Yadav, Abinash Meher) as well as those who attended!

National Science Day is celebrated on 28th February in India as to mark the discovery of Raman Effect by the Noble laureate Indian physicist Sir C V Raman in 1928.This years’ theme is ‘Science and technology for specially-abled persons’. Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur pays tribute to the great soul of India and wishes shining future of Science in India.

Greetings !

We are sharing the highlights from the GSoC session yesterday for those who could not attend. This[1] is the link of our presentation.

Please join Klug on Slack[2] by inviting your self from here - https://klug-slack.heroku...
Join the #gsoc channel and introduce yourself in a line or two. You can find a lot of GSoCers from KGP[3] over there, so don't hesitate.

We had mentioned about FLOSS Manuals[4] for the students. You must give this a read. It is written in a very simple and lucid manner and is one of the most useful resources for you right now.

You should also give a light read to a classic article on How to Ask Smart Questions[5]. And this is not just for GSoC !

And finally, here are a bunch of resources for you to learn Git[6], which you would be using later.

Email us or ask on KLUG slack for any help that we can provide. Do not hesitate. :)

[1] https://docs.google.com/p...
[2] https://klug.slack.com
[3] https://wiki.metakgp.org/...
[4] http://write.flossmanuals...
[5] http://www.catb.org/~esr/...
[6] https://docs.google.com/d...

Cheers !

With the mid-sems safely off the top of our heads, we hope all of you have your eyes focused on the oncoming storm of activities that will remind you of the gripping political scenario of our country, while downscaled to a realisable level. While March has always been associated with a rather political touch, the purpose of this reminder is to bring another one of our research groups to light. Associated with cars, this group stands out owing to the fact that they don't want any drivers to go with their cars, or rather, they want their cars to go without drivers. None other than our own Autonomous Ground Vehicle, Team AGV had a good time during this year's alumni meet with frequent sightings of their Dune Buggy being tested by various alumni on the roads of the campus. Founded in 2010, they have come a long way from then in terms of the technology being incorporated into their vision of a fully automated vehicle.

Read on to find out more:

http://www.scholarsavenue...

The Career Development Center, IIT Kharagpur is proud to present the first edition of 'Career Conclave: A Survivor's Guide to KGP Placements', our initiative to aide placement preparation for the placement season in 2017. The final year batch is currently on campus and willing to help, and we are tapping this opportunity to help you get the finest guidance available on campus. These will be proper preparation sessions, where we'll let you know about the different tests and interview processes in detail and direct you to proper resources for preparation. We look forward to seeing all of you at each of these sessions!

message:
The Open House session for graduating students with the Director which was scheduled to be organised at 6 pm today was cancelled today due to the poor attendance of the aforementioned students.

We often blame the institute for not listening to our grievances, but even when the authorities plan for the events where we can raise issues and suggest measures to the most important problems pertaining in the campus, this lack of response from our side is only going to deter the administration to reach out to the student community again, and we shouldn't expect it as well from now on given that this has happened before as well.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur hereby requests the student community to attend such events in the future and hence fulfil our responsibility towards the institute, especially when the administration is fulfilling theirs'.

The Open House session with the Director for Graduating Students which was scheduled for 27th Feb 2017 was reportedly cancelled today due to the poor attendance of the aforementioned students.
We often blame the institute for not listening to our grievances but when the authorities plan for the events where you can raise issues and suggest measures to the most important problems pertaining in the campus, the result is what we saw today.
It is, therefore a firm request to everyone to attend such events in the future and show a bit of your responsibility toward the institute.

message:
Metakgp shared Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS's photo.

Yes, it is that time of the year again when you have to convert coffee to code. I hope you all know that Google Summer of Code is approaching soon and the Selected Organization list is going to be published on coming Monday.

Therefore, we are planning to conduct a seminar on how to overcome the initial barrier and we will also provide you a lot of insights about GSoC program by people who have cracked GSoC before as students and as mentors. The mentors will provide you even better insights of how they select students and much more stuff.

Thus we hope to see you for the GSoC seminar on Monday, 27th February 2017 at 6.30pm Vikramshila V4.

Cheers!

message:
There must be certain incidents, issues that vexed you to the fullest and forced you to grab a pen, copy or notepad to write your viewpoint about the problems. Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur provides you the stage to raise your voice against or in favour of any campus event, national issue or any incident that intrigue you to write. The article will come under the column "Your Perspective" and should not be personal, it must be linked to the mass and should be on the topic that might help the whole community. The topic for the first article is "Rising number of suicide cases in higher educational institutions and how to mitigate it?" considering recent events.
Entries on topics other than this are also accepted.
Send us the doc file of your article to "editor@awaaziitkgp.org". The article should have the proper heading and use of anytype of slang words is strictly prohibited. Along with the article also provide the name, year, hall and roll number of the writer.
#your_perspective

Mr. Ashutosh Kumar, Executive Director, Jagriti Yatra, on his recent visit to IIT Kharagpur blessed the entire team of Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur through an interactive session which pleased us to our souls. Having founded Awaaz in the 2006-07 session, then his graduating year, he says the foundation and ideologies on which the organisation was based upon at the outset, have been passed on progressively and still rest alive within each and every individual who has been a part and parcel of Awaaz ever since. He seemed to be radically gratified with the several phases of metamorphosis that Awaaz, as a media body, has gone through and commended us for the initiatives taken till date. The evening eventually turned out to be an ultimate delight to everyone in attendance and we hope of coming across similar occasions in the near future.

Once in a while, it must happen that your cycle gets all messed up and you have to rely mainly on the buses to avoid the late entry to the class. Most of the times, the transportation system remains out of the general discussions. But, given the vast campus, this is part and parcel of smooth lives of Kgpians. Let's give a minute to analyse the current situations of the transportation system in the campus.
Fill out the survey here and give your valuable feedback:
http://awaaziitkgp.org/su...

First practical attack on SHA-1 shown by CWI/Google Research!
This should not come as a surprise to anyone - the theoretical problem has been known for years.
If you haven't already made sure to switch VPNs, certificates, SSH services and whatnot to SHA-2, now is a good time!

Read more at http://shattered.io /

Here is another blog post which is written by a student who participated in our Kharagpur Winter of Code 2016. Sayan Sinha has taken out time to write this long after KWoC ended and we appreciate his efforts for the same. It feels great to have created a huge impact on the open source society by this initiative.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur got the opportunity to interact with Mr. Lallit Malik, CFO, Dabur India, Ltd, who shares his experiences being a part of multinational companies since long time. Mr. Malik visited the campus as a part of Leadership Summit, Purvodaya.

Mr.Lalit Malik has over 30 years of experience in various functions of Finance & Accounts, Treasury, Mergers & Acquisitions, Legal, Secretarial & Taxation in India and abroad.
He has previously worked with Sharp & Tannan, Philips, Gillette, Proctor & Gamble, American Express & Moser Baer Limited. He was acclaimed the most influential CFO (from CIMA) and awarded the CFO 100 award from CFO India Magazine. He has also been ranked among the Top 3 Best CFOs by Business World Magazine in the consistent Liquidity Management Category.

For all those who wish to pursue social path or ready to put in efforts into their social startups, Entrepreneurship Cell, IIT Kharagpur is organizing an interactive session on "Journeys to build nations: Jagriti Yatra" with Executive Director, Jagriti, Mr. Ashutosh Kumar.
Mr. Ashutosh is an alumnus of 2007 batch and the founder of Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur who has taken up the path of Social Entrepreneurship to embark change in the world. He is also an IVLP (International Visitor Leadership Program by US Govt.) alumnus and a member of India@75 Taskforce for Skilling and Entrepreneurship, an initiative by CII. message:
"Is there life on other worlds?"
This is the question which has always fascinated the space scientists, not only the scientists but the curious minds out there.

We may have found the most possible answer to this perplexing question through the recent findings by NASA. Astronomers at NASA have found not one-two but seven Earth-sized planets orbiting a star called TRAPPIST-1, and what's more intriguing about it is three of the seven planets are in the Goldilocks Zone or in simpler terms habitable zone. Our planet occupies what in scientific terms called the Goldilocks Zone, which refers to the zone around a star where the temperature is just right - not too cold and not too hot - for liquid water to exist on a planet.

While it's not new to discover the new exoplanets by NASA, the scientists are attributing this discovery of fascinating new solar system to be record-breaking. In the words of Thomas Zurbuchen, associate administrator of the Science Mission Directorate at NASA Headquarters, "The discovery gives us a hint that finding a second Earth is not just a matter of if, but when?"

With the continuation of our web series “Jewels of Kgp”, this time we bring you none other than this year’s Technical Oscar award winner Mr. Parag Havaldar, for his brilliant work in the development of expression-based facial performance-capture technology at Sony Pictures Imageworks. A former kgpian and a prestigious alumnus who raised all our heads high in the whole world. So, let’s walk through his life steps and discover how he achieved this ultimate pinnacle.

Congratulations ISRO for creating History! The Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV-C37) has today successfully put 104 satellites in orbit in a single go from Satish Dhawan Space Centre Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh, surpassing the previous Russian Federation's 37 in 2014. The constellation includes satellites from the US and ISRO's customers including Germany, Israel, Kazakhstan, the Netherlands, Switzerland and the United Arab Emirates. Notably, the launch vehicle PSLV, lovingly known as 'the Workhorse of ISRO', has put some of India's most celebrated missions like Chandrayaan-1, Mars Orbiter Mission and India's first space observatory, Astrosat.

Courtesy: Press Information Bureau, Ministry of Information & Broadcasting, Government of India.

|| KNOW YOUR RESEARCH GROUPS - 2||

Michael Bay once said, "Fast cars are my only vice".
The famous director of the Transformers series of movies might have been referring to his absolutely amazing portrayal of the self-transforming and AI-infused automobiles fighting to save the world, while on the other side of the world, we have also seen cars spend most of their time in air rather than on the ground, either fulfilling their role of depicting the so-called action packed sequences or flying just for the sake of all the nonsensical happenings of the world.

Jokes aside, cars have been integral parts of our lives since the day Henry Ford learned to spread the art of traversing without walking. As a part of a pro-technological community, it's not a surprise that our students have successfully entered the realm of this vast land and have been setting landmarks all across. TeamKART, our own Formula SAE team has been involved in all the aspects of automotive engineering for more than a decade now, and has earned quite a few accolades along the way.

Recently, they were awarded the second prize for their business presentation in Formula Bharat 2017, an engineering design competition held in the last week of January this year.

How they came about and what do they do? Read on to find out.

http://www.scholarsavenue...

#Poll_of_the_Week_5_result
#Relevance_of_NSS
About 500 students per year have NSS (National service scheme) as their extra academic activity. But it has frequently been brought in general consensus whether or not this scheme is proving beneficial for either sector of people influenced by it. Students, professors, and the villagers- all had varying opinions relating to the topic and hence, was put under scrutiny in the form of a poll. The results revealed that as much as 52% of the students wanted to work as devoted NSS members but only when the projects will be innovative rather than the conventional ones. 14% of students raised the issue of relaxing the second year students from the NSS duty citing the academic loads. Another 13% of the students were not interested at all, while one-fifth of them seemed more or less devoted to the social cause.
Henceforth is the complete article and the results of the poll:
http://awaaziitkgp.org/ns...

Purvodaya 2017 witnessed the much awaited Leadership Summit, attended by successful business leaders from the corporate world as well as eminent achievers from other walks of life.

The panelists included some of the prestigious and proclaimed leaders and entrepreneurs of the country like Mr. Tarun Katial, CEO, Reliance Broadcast network, Mr. Ashish Sommaiyaa, MD and CEO, Motilal Oswal Asset Management, and Mr. Lalit Malik, CFO, Dabur India Ltd.

Mr. Sumit Sharma, COO, Lacoste India, Mr. Sandeep Lakhina, EVP, Dentsu Aegis Network and Mr. PV Sheshadri, CEO, Future Supply Chain Solutions Ltd shared their experiences and thoughts with the students.

Mitali Mukherjee, Business Journalist, and former Markets Editor of CNBC served as moderator in the Panel Discussion that served as a great platform to interact with eminent Business Leaders who came together to share their experiences and thoughts.

The summit served as a cauldron of interaction and brought about mutual learning for everyone involved.

message:
The Scholars' Avenue shared their post.

"Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic" - Arthur.C.Clarke

While this quote is universal, it holds particular importance considering our institute's relationship with fostering technology and innovation. We have come a long way in terms of catching up with the advancements in technology all around us, and yet the road hasn't grow any shorter. There are many others ahead of us in various fields, but we have been taught to look at this as an opportunity to push ourselves to the front of the race by giving everything we've got.
In this direction, we felt it was our responsibility to shine some light on the major players in this game, who've made KGP their base and strive to push all boundaries in their respective fields.
We present to you "Know Your Research Groups" - a small effort from our side to make sure that the midnight oil burnt by a fraction of students to keep the technological flame of our KGP'ian culture alive, is not lost in vain.

First up, we have the ARK - Aerial Robotics Kharagpur.

http://www.scholarsavenue...

message:
"Keep your chin up and head straight, and look for the larger picture" - Sandeep Lakhina, Executive Vice President, Dentsu Aegis Network

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur brings you an interaction with Executive Vice President, Dentsu Aegis Network, Mr. Sandeep Lakhina, who visited the campus as a part of Purvodaya 2017.

Mr. Lakhina brings over two decades of rich experience in marketing, sales/BD, & business operations, across multiple industries in media & entertainment, marketing & communication agencies, CPG, consulting, and retail. Prior to Mint, he has successfully lead the business for Starcom MediaVest Group as the COO-South Asia. In India, prior to that, he launched & serviced the Vodafone business, and managed Philips & Bata at Euro RSCG. He was one of the early birds in the retail space as the marketing head for Ebony Retail.

In this direction, we felt it was our responsibility to shine some light on the major players in this game, who've made KGP their base and strive to push all boundaries in their respective fields.
We present to you "Know Your Research Groups" - a small effort from our side to make sure that the midnight oil burnt by a fraction of students to keep the technological flame of our KGP'ian culture alive, is not lost in vain.

First up, we have the ARK - Aerial Robotics Kharagpur.

http://www.scholarsavenue...

Purvodya 2017, the annual fest organized by Vinod Gupta School of Management presented the guest lecture by none other than the famous Dr. Pawan Agrawal, an international speaker and well known as the 'Management Guru' in Netaji auditorium today. He discussed the history of this prestigious Dabbawala business, its roots and how the business expanded dramatically owing to the principles and the values they exhibit. He gave an insight into the organizational and working structure of the Dabbawala system and told how they performed with so much perfection even when most of their workers are on average under-matriculate. He inspired the audience about having passion, commitment and dedication to our work and always being on toes in terms of time management. The lecture ended with Dr. Pawan being honored and he cheerfully giving his signature dabbawala caps and tiffins to all.

“We need to build skills beyond just technical knowledge.”

The inauguration ceremony of Purvodaya, the annual B-School Fest of Vinod Gupta School of Management, witnessed the promising address by Mr. Awdhesh Krishna, Global HR, Nomura. Mr. Awdhesh Krishna emphasised on Creativity, Emotional Intelligence and Cognitive Flexibility among the youth of the nation.

He further encouraged the students to follow their dreams and passion, and take risks in life rather than following the mob. Mr. Awdhesh Krishna spoke about the growing era of entrepreneurship and emphasised on its importance in country’s economy. In his words, “What matters is not Competence but CHARACTER, not success but SIGNIFICANCE.”

A battle witnessing the fierce clash of intellect is waged in the east every year. Simple strategies, smart tactics and sustainable solutions will mettle with triumph. 'Purvodaya' - Signifying the Rise of East marks the commencement of the battle and this time too, the sun has risen in the east marking the arrival of PURVODAYA’17. The stage is all set for the prestigious annual B-School fest of the Vinod Gupta School of Management, IIT Kharagpur (VGSoM) which is bound to witness the showcasing of the business acumen by some of the best budding business minds across the country. With the world moving toward smart and simple solutions to ensure a sustainable growth and living, the current edition of Purvodaya is built around the theme “Simple- Smart- Sustainable” to emphasize the importance of such solutions in the dynamic world.
Information about the various events and detailed schedule are here: http://purvodaya.in/home/...

“Blindness is not a disability or defect, it’s just a characteristic”,
said Mr Pratish Datta, who despite being visually impaired, has reached great heights of success in his life. Currently, he is doing his PhD in the field of “Cryptology and Security systems” at IIT KGP. After graduating with Mathematics stream from St. Xavier’s College, Kolkata, he joined IIT KGP in 2010 for MSc. course. He was the best academic performer in this course, for which he received “J C Bose Memorial Gold Medal” from the President of India, Sri Pranab Mukherjee.

#Jewels_of_Kgp #JC_Bose_Memorial_Gold_Medal #Pratish_Datta

According to an analysis by British software firm Sage, the IITs are among the best in the world at churning out founders of unicorns—i.e. privately-held startups valued at $1 billion or more. US-based Stanford University claimed the top rank with 51 unicorn founders, followed by Harvard University with 37. The University of California came third with 18 unicorn founders and IITs came fourth with 12 founders. The horde of entrepreneurs coming out of IITs has caught everyone’s fancy. And we hope that we are going to see more of these in coming years!

National Entrepreneurship Awards | Online competition

The National Entrepreneurship Awards have been instituted by the Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship (MSDE) to encourage a culture of entrepreneurship across the country. These premier awards seek to recognise and honour entrepreneurs and entrepreneurship ecosystem builders for their outstanding efforts.

The awards are going to be organised on 30th January 2017 and as a part of the awards an online competition has also been launched. As a part of the competition, all the budding entrepreneurs are requested to share their ideas on the Facebook Page and Twitter page of the Awards with the #iCanDoBusiness. The idea can be in any form - a short video in the form of an elevator pitch or an infographic. The best ideas would be recognised by MSDE.

For more information, see the brief notes attached

In case you can't exactly remember information which still bestows in your dusty old civics book regarding why today is so important, this would be of great help. TSA wishes a Happy Republic Day to all the readers! An excerpt: A democracy is a form of government in which all eligible citizens have the right to equal participation, either directly or through elected representatives, in the proposal, development, and creation of laws. To put it in very simple terms, it is a form of government where people choose their own government and the voice of the majority rules. Once the majority is established, the minority has no say. Even in a republic, it's the voice of the majority that rules through chosen representatives; however, there is a charter or constitution of basic rights that protects the minority from being completely unrepresented or overridden.

One of our alumnus Mr. Krishan Khanna of 1961 batch is visiting the campus between 19th Jan to 22nd Jan and also in between 26th Jan to 29th Jan. He is the trustee and founder of "i Watch ", a non-profit foundation which is on a mission of service "transforming India and Nation Building". Its main focus is governance and education and how it has a direct influence on the economy and employment. The focus is to highlight the latent potential of India which will be fully unleashed once the human capital of its people is fully empowered. For his works he has received appreciation letters from our late president Dr. A P J Abdul Kalam, and NIIT Chairman Rajendra S Pawar.

He has won many national and international awards in his 25 years of social service. He has put all his ideas in the book called "Transforming India" which is meant for a Mind-Set-Change of civil society. To support his charity he wishes that every KGPian should have a copy of his book. His book will be delivered to your room if you express your interest through the google form here.

The initial pages of the book are attached

The start of this new year has been blemished with a dark cloud over all of IIT KGP that, possibly, could have been avoided. It is with great regret that we inform you that Lokesh Meena, a 3rd year undergraduate student of the Civil Department, is no more. All investigations point to the cause of suicide. He disappeared from his hall, the Radha Krishnan Hall of Residence, on Sunday, reportedly after calling his mother and stating his wish to die, switching off his phone right after the call. Alarmed, his mother had informed his friends triggering a campus wide search. His body was found by the officials on Monday morning, in front of a train track some 20 kms away from our campus.
His friends and well wishers said he showed no signs of suicide, although he did tackle with depression and anxiety. A recent detection of tuberculosis and an alleged quarrel with his family on some issue might have pushed him to take such an extreme step, reports suggest.
Lokesh was and always will fondly be remembered as a studious and joyful soul. It is still a shock to the KGP community that incidents of suicide keep plaguing our hallowed institute. Such an extreme decision doesn't take a day to materialise.
We regret the death of a fellow KGPian, which was uncalled for, and also urge everyone of you to keep a close check on any unusual behaviors you might observe among those close to you.
May his soul rest in peace!

It seems that brain drain is a myth now. Not even 200 of total 10,000 students from the Indian Institutes of Technology took up positions outside India last year. Fifty students, who make up the largest contingent, will be leaving from IIT Bombay, followed by 40 from Delhi, 25 from Kharagpur, 19 from Kanpur, 13 from Madras, 17 from Roorkee and five from Guwahati as per a leading daily.
"Twenty years ago, 80% of the B.Tech. class used to go abroad. Now these numbers are very low. Compared to 20 years ago, a very small fraction of students go abroad today. This is contrary to the general perception," said IIT Delhi director V Ramgopal Rao.
Deepak Phatak, chair professor at IIT Bombay, said, "A large number of our students are not seeking jobs outside India. I conducted exit interviews and found that what students perceive is that the land of opportunity is here."
There is now a changing perception that quality jobs are available in India as well. Moreover, with global companies setting up offices in India, IITians can hope for placement here itself. For example, students can join Google in Bennigana Halli in Bengaluru instead of Mountain View, California.

Looking for motivated Interns & Consultants

We are looking for enthusiastic, self motivated , hardworking students & consultants to work with our research groups in the areas of 1) Natural Language Processing, 2) Deep Learning on Text & Multivariate Time Series 3) Chatbot frameworks and 4) Reinforcement Learning. Location: JFWTC, GE Global Research, Bangalore.

Minimum duration of 6 months, extendable, start date flexible. Stipend will be provided.

This work can potentially be part of thesis or project work towards a degree (BTech, MS/Mtech, PhD) , and will be publishable.

At GE Research, we are pioneering the Industrial Internet of Things. Combining the physics of the equipment with AI techniques using the data being generated by the equipment and other associated data sources is key to building Digital Twins of the machines – allowing us to operate them optimally and predict failures in advance. Additionally, we will build conversational interfaces allowing us to talk to the machines & relevant applications.

Key requirements:
1. Strong programmer – Java, Python, C++

2. Strong foundation in Machine Learning / Statistics

3. Text Mining & NLP

4. Deep Learning using Caffe/TensorFlow/MxNET


Pl send CV to babu@ ge.com

Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur is organizing the screening of "Challenge of Change", a documentary film on the life and teachings of Jiddu Krishnamurti will be screened followed by Question and Answer session with Mr. P. Chhabra and Prof. P. Krishna, at Gargi Auditorium from 6.30pm on 11th January, 2017!

This will be followed up by a lecture by Dr Krishna on 12th January at Gargi Auditorium on "Science and Spirituality".

Jiddu Krishnamurti is regarded globally as one of the greatest thinkers and religious teachers of all time. Krishnamurti books, videos, and audios and other materials on him will be available for exhibition and sale at Gargi Seminar Hall (during program) and Staff Club (near Tech Market) from 12-15 January, 2017.

Fill in this form to register for the event :
https://docs.google.com/f...

With an excellent start of the year by having Sunder Pichai back on our campus, there is no doubt that Kgp junta is motivated and inspired by him. After the event, we talked to a few people about the event. Check out what they have to say:
#BackOnCampus.

Technology, IIT Kharagpur shared Technology Transfer Group , IIT Kharagpur's photo.

In continuation of the ongoing Patent Drive, efforts are being made to protect the inventions by the students and researchers. We would like to identify and protect the technologies to be displayed in the upcoming Techno-management festival Kshitij™.

In this regard all the institute participants of Kshitij events especially

(i) Eureka, (ii) Embetronics, (iii) Droid Blitz, (iv) Conquest, (v) Arm Of Achelous, (vi) Sandrover, (vii) B.R.I.C.K.S, (viii) Kryotech, (ix) Anadigix and (x) Initiative Prakriti are requested to send an abstract along with required drawings of their invention to submissions@ktj.in.

"The deadline for the institute participants has been exclusively extended up to the 12th of Jan "

The patentable inventions will be recommended for filing after scrutiny by the expert techno-legal committee. Please be assured that Institute will provide all necessary support to protect your valuable inventions.

Please note that all your valuable inventions need to be protected by filing the patent before disclosing to the public. This is an excellent opportunity to protect and look for the possible marketability and commercial viability of your inventions. Such protection prevents the unauthorized use of your invention and provides a meaningful exclusionary right to the patent holder.

The details of Kshitij events can be found in the following link: http://ktj.in/#ktj/Events

The Scholars' Avenue recently had the opportunity to meet Prof. William G. Hoover, an eminent computational physicist from USA, and his wife, Prof. Carol Hoover. They were on campus for teaching a course on ‘Nonequilibrium statistical mechanics and molecular dynamics’ offered in GIAN during 5-16 December 2016. Dr. Prasad Matukumilli, a student of Prof. Baidurya Bhattacharya took the interview on behalf of TSA.
http://www.scholarsavenue...

Sundar Pichai, CEO Google and Distinguished Alumnus of IIT Kharagpur, will be visiting the campus on 5th January to address the students.
Sunder Pichai had passed out from the institute in 1993 with a BTech in metallurgical and materials engineering. He then went on to pursue an MS in Engineering and Materials Science from Stanford University and an MBA from the Wharton School.
Later on he joined Google in 2004 as its vice president of product management, where he led the team working on Google's Chrome browser and operating system, before being elevated as its CEO last year.
It is an excellent opportunity for every individual to be a part of this discussion titled 'A journey back to the past to inspire the future' being held at TOAT on 5th of January.

India today successfully test-fired its longest range indigenous inter-continental surface-to-surface nuclear capable ballistic missile AGNI-5 from Abdul Kalam Island off Odisha coast. The 17m long missile weighing about 50 tonnes and capable of carrying a nuclear warhead of 1.5 tonnes can target almost entire China and Pakistan and can even reach targets in Europe.

Proudly, India is the sixth country only after France, China, Russia, US and UK to have a nuclear missile with over 5,000 km range.

Congratulations to the entire DRDO team!

Pre-Case released!
The wait is over! Business Club, IIT Kharagpur in association with Entrepreneurship Cell, IIT Kharagpur presents the first round of the Indian Case Challenge 2017, India’s biggest case study competition.
Gear up yourselves as teams from the best colleges in India compete to prove their business entrepreneurial mettle. Confronted with a real life case scenario, just strong business skills and financial know-how won’t be enough. Only those with a spark of creativity and a zeal for realizing business opportunities will make it through.
We look forward to ingenious strategies and innovative ideas. Wishing best of luck to the participating teams!
The case will be sent to the registered teams via email. Last date of submission for the preliminary round is 10th January 2017.
If you have not registered yet, head over to http://bclub.co.in/icc201...

On 16th December a document was issued as a response to the students' plea and their demands. You can read the response here - http://bit.ly/deansa_resp...
And today, students received a mail stating -
"Institute will very sympathetically consider the request by the students and when the Deputy Director returns, the exact amount of assistance will be decided in the month of January 2017. The students are requested to pay the exact amount as has been decided and subsequently, it will be adjusted to the extent of the support given by the institute."
In response to that students organized a protest, and have sat on a hunger strike. Have a look at what students said regarding the fee hike and why student community thinks that they are not liable to pay the hiked fee as per the proposed changes.

The Scholars' Avenue shared Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur's post.

Kanpur finally delivered on the promise of #3BaarLagataar, beating the closest competitor, Delhi by a whopping 43 points. The efforts of the participants paid off and they gave their institution the best gift to end 2016.
story: The Scholars' Avenue shared Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur's post.

message: Student community mostly comprising of Research Scholars have sat on indefinite hunger strike in protest against administration's decision of HOH fee hike. They gathered in front of the main gate, have closed all the gates of the academic area and all the traffic has been stopped. Students said that they would sit there until Director himself comes to address them.

Demanding the roll back in the recent fee hike, a large number of research scholars gathered and marched together from gymkhana to main building covering Hall Management Centre at around 5 PM today. The March was in order to submit a petition with the signature of approximately 1100 scholars to Chairman HMC, Dean PGS & Research Scholars, DOSA (Dean of Student Affairs) and Director's Offices.

Here are the few important points of their petition
• The expenses under Hostel Establishment Charges are unjustified so it should be rolled back.
• Research scholars availing hostel facilities are not provided with House Rent Allowance so per head charge of 3174 for that purpose is not justified and they should be exempted from them.
• Research scholars, not availing hostel facilities (students staying in VSRC, G-type quarters, Zakir Hussain Apartments and outside campus) should be the exempted from the Hostel Seat Rent and Hostel Establishment Charges.

They told that the research scholars are the hardest hit section, with their limited income and effectively zero benefits, have been facing monotonically increasing fee, semester after semester. Further, the scholars told that the hike in the fee is unethical as a substantial section of the research scholars here have to support their family using this stipend and will not be able to make ends meet if this fee hike is implemented.

HMC office has taken their petition and assured the protesters that further decisions in this regard will be taken latest by Friday midnight.

message:
Around 300 students, mostly postgraduates and research scholars, marched and gathered in front of the HMC office today at 5:00 PM to protest the recent hike in mess overhead charges from Rs 8250 to Rs 15800. The increase is meant to the cover the additional costs from the following:
1. Salary and pension payment of all private mess workers will be brought at par with that of institute mess workers.
2. 20% GST will be charged on mess food and subsidy on private mess food will be removed
Additionally, the move seeks to factor in inflation, miscellaneous expenses, changes due to 7th pay commission etc. For further details, please refer to attachments.

Further negotiations are happening on this front, stay tuned for updates.

message:
As Day 1 of the 51st edition of Inter IIT Sports Meet got over yesterday at IIT Kanpur, KGPians gave a highly promising a start to IIT Kharagpur. Day 1 saw some earlier records being broken and some new records being created.

Triple Jump :
Lokeshwar Rao grabbed the Gold Medal in the event of Inter IIT Triple Jump also broke the previous record by setting a new milestone of 13.68 metres.

Men’s Shot Put :
Abin won silver in Inter IIT Men’s Shot Put Event and brought glory to IIT Kharagpur.

Men’s Basketball :
IIT Kharagpur registered a victory over IIT Madras with a score of 47-32.

Women’s Basketball :
IIT Kharagpur defeated IIT Hyderabad by 16-7.

Men’s Lawn Tennis :
IIT Kharagpur defeated IIT Jodhpur in Inter IIT Lawn Tennis Men’s Tournament.

Women’s Badminton :
IIT Kharagpur beat IIT Delhi

Squash :
IIT Kharagpur defeated IIT Roorkee by 2-1.

Women’s Table Tennis :
IIT Kharagpur scored a victory over IIT Patna.

Men’s Table Tennis :
IIT Kharagpur defeated IIT Ropar in Table Tennis Tournament.

Men’s Volleyball :
IIT Kharagpur registered a victory over IIT Hyderabad.

Cricket :
IIT Kharagpur defeated IIT Gandhinagar by 4 wickets in a close contest. It was a nail-biting finish by IIT Kharagpur in the last over. Ayush and Sachin picked up two wickets each and Kaushal scored a quick 33 down the order.

800 Metres :
Jagdeesh qualified for the finals in Inter IIT 800 Metres Men’s Tournament.
Bharti and Hima have qualified for the finals in Inter IIT 800 Metres Women’s Tournament.

100 Metres :
Anand Raj qualified for the finals in 100 metres men’s contest.

Football :
IIT Kharagpur finished a draw against IIT BHU with the final score of 1-1.

Men’s Badminton :
IIT Kharagpur lost to IIT BHU by 0-3.

Women’s Lawn Tennis :
IIT Kharagpur lost to IIT Kanpur.

Men’s Hockey :
IIT Kharagpur lost to IIT BHU by 0-4.

In conclusion, it was a great day for IIT Kharagpur. Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the winners and wishes good luck for the upcoming events.

Chess
IIT Kgp secured a silver medal in the event.

The 51st edition of Inter IIT Sports Meet was inaugurated successfully today at Kanpur. The Opening Ceremony was marked by the remarkable presence of the Chief Guest, Mr. K. K, Sharma, Chief Secretary of Delhi and also a former IAS Officer. Paralympic athletes, Devendra Jhajharia and Varun Bhati were the Guests of Honour for the ceremony. Being a javelin thrower in F46 events, Devendra Jhajharia is first and the only Indian to win two Paralympic gold medals. On the other hand, Varun Bhati has been a bronze medalist at the Summer Paralympic Games, 2016. The event witnessed the assembly of participants and contingents followed by Flag Hoisting and March Past. After the oath taking ceremony and the torch run, Dignitaries addressed the audience and the participants and encouraged the youth towards sports and wished good luck to the participants. International Hand Shadow artist, Amar Sen, and Enthrall Crew, a group of yoga and acrobat professionals entertained through their phenomenal performances. The ceremony ended with an amazing performance by the rock band, Indian Ocean.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur wishes good luck to all the participants.

They are putting a spotlight on 5 women entrepreneurs who are part of the first accelerated batch of IIT Delhi based WEE Foundation. These entrepreneurs are building well differentiated sustainable businesses in diverse sectors.

"It’s time for each of us to step up for human rights. There is no action that is too small: wherever you are, you can make a difference. Together, let’s take a stand for more humanity" - UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein

Human Rights Day is observed every year on December 10.This Day calls on everyone to stand up for someone's rights. Disrespect for basic human rights continues to be wide-spread in all parts of the globe. Messages of intolerance and hatred prey on our fears. Humane values are under attack.

We must reaffirm our common humanity. Wherever we are, we can make a real difference. We, the future citizens must exercise our rights to bring a change.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur urges all to take stand for rights and for more humanity.

#Fee_Hike
As notified earlier, the Hostel Overhead Charge (HOH) which is being collected from each student during semester registration has been reviewed and the total fee under this category has been increased from Rs. 8,250 to Rs. 15,800. The decision was taken by the HMC and the Students Senate including the Vice President, Gymkhana, all Hall Presidents and the Second Senate Members. The main reasons behind this hike are stated below.
1.One of the major reason behind this hike is the 7th pay commission. As a result of which the salaries of both the HMC and contractual sweeping staffs have been increased. The salary of temporary workers has increased from Rs.278 per day to Rs.350 per day.
2.One more reason behind this hike is the new policy of Tax and wage sharing. Currently, all students bear the cost towards salary and benefits of HMC employees and all outsourced sweeping workers. It has been decided that the salary of all private mess workers and tax on food served in private messes should as well be shared by all students so that those staying in halls with private mess are not disadvantaged.
3. There is also an increase in the HOH from 300 to 600. This amount is used to pay towards the annual maintenance of aqua guards,coolers, roti making machines, repairs of machines in mess, repair of flood lights in grounds[footer, cricket etc.] of hall, purchase of any new machines in mess, any new construction like badminton court etc and allied activities. The smaller halls were not able to cope with all of these with just a small amount of 300. Also, there is an increment in the comprehensive menu in all the halls to Rs. 95 per person. So, due to these factors, the HOH has increased from 300 to 600.

We would like to thanks Ksheera Sagar, a member of Student's senate for insights on the hike.
Keeping these things in mind, here is our 5th “poll of the week”.
“What are your views on the recent hike in the Hostel Overhead Charge (HOH) and Hall Establishment Charge (HEC)?”
We’ll be presenting the results of this poll to the administration, so do participate and let everyone know how justified it is. You can opt for multiple options and can also put your views or suggestions on the “Other” option.
Visit the link below to express your views on this hike.
http://bit.ly/awaaziitkgp...
#Aap_Ki_Raay_5

message:
A recent study by researchers of our institute has yielded a method to increase the production of biofuel from common aquatic weeds, such as water hyacinths. The paper, authored by Saikat Chakraborty- faculty member at the Department of Chemical Engineering and lead researcher, Bioenergy Research group- and Sajal Kanti Dutta has discovered a pore-scale phenomenon which can lead to a "fourfold increase in the yields of fermentable sugars and bioethanol" from hemicelluloses, thereby making them an abundant and cheap source of biofuel. Further advancements in this field can help combat climate change by reducing our reliance on fossil fuels.
http://swarajyamag.com/in...

As notified earlier, the Hostel Overhead Charge (HOH) which is being collected from each student during semester registration has been renamed and the total fee under this category has been increased from Rs. 8,250 to Rs. 15,800. The decision was taken by the HMC and the Students Senate including the Vice President, Gymkhana, All Hall Presidents and the Second Senate Members.

We would like to thank Ksheera Sagar, a member of Students' Senate for explaining the increase in the fee.

"The main reason is for the increase is the 7th pay commission. The money [7950 per sem per student ] from all students is used to pay salaries of all HMC staff [297 in number] and all sweeping workers in all halls [nearly 500 in number],& to purchase all the sweeping and cleaning materials for all halls. As a result of the pay commission, all the salaries were increased of both the HMC staff and also the contractual sweeping staff . The major chunk of the increment is due to the hike in salaries. Another component of the hike is due to the new policy of TAX sharing and wage sharing. That means in the old policy[till now] the food tax on the food in private mess and the salary of the private mess workers in private mess were used to bear by private mess students only and also the private mess students used to bear the salary burden of HMC staff and sweeping staff as usual while the students at HMC mess use to bear only salaries of HMC staff , sweeping workers and sweeping materials. So in the policy [till now] the students at HMC mess were at an upper hand as they were not sharing any wages of private mess workers nor the HMC mess food has tax. This advantage ultimately led to the uplift of HMC meeses where comparatively good quality food is served than private messes. So according to the new policy, the tax of food in private mess will be bear by all students irrespective of HMC or private, the Mess workers salaries[HMC & private] will be bear by all students irrespective of HMC or private. and the sweeping workers salary , sweeping materials cost will be bear as usual. So the pay commission and the new policy of TAX and wage sharing makes the 7950 to 15200.

The HOH has also been increased from 300 to 600

This amount is called HOH[hall overhead fund], this is in general used to pay towards the annual maintenance of aqua guards, coolers , roti making machines, repairs of machines in mess, repair of flood lights in grounds[footer, cricket etc.] of hall, purchase of any new machines in mess, any new construction like badminton court etc and allied activities. The smaller halls with boarders strength less than 350 cannot do all the maintenance work with the HOH amount[300] obtained every sem from the students and the bigger halls with strength greater than 450 fell short in creating new facilities for their boarders like new courts, new instruments etc. So keeping all this in vision the money from 300 to 600 is increased. The HOH in every hall is controlled by warden so its allotment for maintenance and development of the hall is entirely on the discretion of the warden.

Researchers at the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur have successfully developed a small device to measure the pH of any solution, with preliminary studies showing its usefulness to measure the pH of blood. Unlike the conventional approach of measuring the pH of blood potentiometrically, the device works by measuring the impedance. The device was found to have satisfactory pH sensitivity in the physiological pH range.The feat was achieved by Prof Soumen Das of the School of Medical Science and Technology, Prasoon Awasthi, Dr. Ranjan Mukherjee and Siva Prakasam.
For more information, you can visit the following link:
http://www.thehindu.com/s...

It's been 3 days since the placement session at KGP has started. On the day 1 of the placement itself, a total of 125 offers were made in 29 different companies that visited our campus on day 1 while 25 students have been shortlisted for the waitlist. Though on the second day the unnumbered of companies visiting KGP has reduced to 26 but still 128 students got offers as well. 26 companies also came to KGP on day 3, however, on the day 3, 97 offers were made.

Till day 3, a total of 83 companies (considering different profiles of companies) have visited the campus and a total of 350 offers were given with some getting multiple offers too, while 60 students made it to the waitlist.

The highest number of students got placed from the department of Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering is 89 while 66 students got placed from the department of Computer Science.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the successful students and wishes best of luck for the remaining days of placement.

message: In a bid to attract more international talent, the IITs for the first time are planning to hold their entrance tests in Singapore, UAE, Ethiopia and SAARC nations, except Pakistan next year to select foreign students for undergraduate and postgraduate courses. Foreign students who are selected to the Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) through JEE (Advanced) or GATE exams will have to pay an annual fee of Rs6 lakh per year. According to officials in the HRD ministry, the issue was discussed at a meeting of the IIT council and as per the decision taken the annual tuition fee has been fixed at Rs6 lakh per annum while suitable scholarships may be provided on a certain basis.

Mr. Dolores O' Riordan, Vice Precident, The Global Engagement yesterday visited the Food Processing Division of the Department of Agricultural & Food Engineering. He was accompanied by Prof. Colm O'Donnel, Principal, School of Biosystems & Food Engineering, UCD, Dublin, Ireland.
Prof. H N Mishra, Department of Agricultural and Food Engineering told Awaaz that they ratified an MoU with IIT Kharagpur on the establishment of a Food Technology and Entrepreneurship Park, Make in India initiatives on Nutrition, Food Security & Health and on Student Exchange Program. In order to increase the participation of KGPians in open source competitions like Google Summer of Code, Outreachy et al, Kharagpur Open Source Society has come up with a month long program called KWoC to help students prepare for such events.

Kharagpur Winter of Code or KWoC is a month long program wherin students will be introduced to the world of open source, and trained to contribute to it.Ex-GSoCers and other leading open source contributors would serve as their mentors in this quest.

Go to http://kwoc.kossiitkgp.in... / to register for the program as a student or submit your own project.

In order to increase the participation of IIT Kharagpur in various open-source programs like Google Summer of Code, Outreachy and much more, a new initiative by Kharagpur Open Source Society has been taken for the students of IIT Kharagpur to help them prepare for many prestigious open source programs.

Kharagpur Winter of Code (KWoC) is a December-long online program where the students will get a unique experience of software development while being coached by mentors all around the open source world as well as many ex-GSoCers.

Go to http://kwoc.kossiitkgp.in... and register yourself. The program starts on 1st December. The program is open to all students regardless of their department, course, degree or the year.

Also, if you want to be a mentor in the program, go to the website and host your project.

message:
A fire broke out in the Wind Tunnel Lab in the Department of Aerospace Engineering at around 10:00 P.M. on 15/11/16.
The guard control room received a distress call from Srinivasan, a research scholar, at around 10:15 PM. Three fire brigades were immediately called to control the fire.
Srinivasan was in his cabin which is in the Wind Tunnel Lab. He noticed smoke coming out and also heard some sound. He went to investigate and saw that a part of the lab had caught fire. He immediately called his supervisor Prof. K P Sinhamahapatra and the control room to inform about the fire and the fire was quickly brought under control. Nobody was injured in the accident but the lab was severely damaged. The lab may not be functional for a few days and the students are advised to stay away form the lab until further notice.

message:
The Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) have sought Rs. 22,000 crore from the Ministry of Human Resource Development that is needed to spend over the next five years to improve their infrastructure and rise in global rankings. QS World University Rankings for 2016-17 had seen six of the IITs slump down from their positions. The money has been sought as part of Project Vishwajeet, which HRD Ministry wants to implement in order to make the IITs reach within the ranks of the top 100 universities in the world by 2018 and within the top 50 by 2020.
The IITs targeted are Delhi, Bombay, Kanpur, Kharagpur, Madras, Roorkee and Guwahati. Of the nearly Rs 22,000 crore, IIT-Kharagpur has sought Rs 3,700 crore, IIT-Bombay Rs 2,250 crore, IIT-Delhi Rs 2,400 crore, IIT-Kanpur Rs 2,475 crore, IIT-Madras Rs 2,800 crore, IIT-Guwahati Rs 2,695 crore and IIT-Roorkee Rs 5,550 crore. The money will go into improving "research output, faculty, infrastructure and international outlook."

The word career means a person's "course or progress through life". It has proven itself to be more complex and overloaded than string theory and sure has taken away the sleep of many young people.

Carrying forward the series 'aap ki raay', the results of the third poll showcase the factors prioritized by students while choosing a career. Evidently, a lion's share of the students aren't sure about their career goals and are still exploring the possible options. A little more than one-sixth felt that running after money is the need of the hour and is fairly justified to do so.

About 18% are following their interests, ignoring factors such as job security and others whereas about 7% are blindly following the herd. Just the 1% are working on their own startup ideas and have opted out of campus placements. Another 8% have planned for higher studies including options like an MS or a PhD degree, IAS, etc. and have as well opted out of campus placements. More than 17% have an interest in two of the latter options but would still like to keep placements from the campus as a backup.

WorldQuant is back with it's Challenge Autumn Alphathon. The competition is up and running.

Duration : October 28 - December 18, 2016

The WorldQuant Challenge provides interested candidates with an opportunity to test their trading ideas and strategies using WebSim, WorldQuant’s web-based market simulator. Qualified candidates earn points for quality alphas, and these points can lead to Bronze, Silver and Gold status. Individuals who achieve Silver and Gold may be considered for Research Consultant positions with WorldQuant.

The Autumn Alphathon makes the WorldQuant challenge even more exciting through the potential for up to 65 participants to receive a ONE-TIME SPECIAL STIPEND, at WorldQuant’s discretion, to individuals who progress to the Gold level.

You can register for the challenge by following the link below:
https://websim.worldquant...

For more information and particulars on the challenge, you can refer the guidelines here:
https://websim.worldquant...

Human rights are rights inherent to all human beings, whatever our nationality, place of residence, sex, national or ethnic origin, color, religion, language, or any other status. We are all equally entitled to our human rights without discrimination. These rights are all interrelated, interdependent and indivisible.
In our new section, we are going to introduce the various rights that we often hear about but don’t know about it in depth. Being the Voice of Kgp , Awaaz IIT Kharagpur takes this initiative as a responsibility to make you all aware about your ‘Human Rights’. We will start this section with the Right to Information, popularly known as the RTI.

On the occasion of 141st Patel Jayanti, Patel Hall launched a "Unity Drive" which comprised of Cloth Donation(held on 3rd Nov) and Blood Donation event( held on 5th Nov) .
While the cloth donation event manifested joy among the villagers, the blood donation event resulted in a collection of 134 units of blood.

The Hall President of Patel Hall, Mr Chandra Mohan Meena said " We are the young generation and we have to think about the social issues which our country is facing and have to find ways to work on it. "If we won't then who will?"

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates Patel hall for successful completion of the event and also urges other halls to take such social initiative.

|| Important Notice ||
As per the orders from the Prime Minister of India, from midnight of November 8, 2016, Rs. 500 and Rs.1000 will cease to be legal tender i.e. these notes will just be papers from tomorrow.
The ATMs will not function till November 9, and in some places till November 10 too.

Here’s what you need to know:
# All banks will remain closed for public work on November 9.
# Deposit currently used notes of Rs 500 and Rs 1000 in post office accounts or banks by December 30, 2016. There will be no limit on the deposit amounts.
# Exchange old notes of Rs 500 and Rs 1000 at any bank, head post office or sub-post office by showing ID proof. The limit for this is Rs 4000 upto Nov 24.
# There’ll be a limit on withdrawal of Rs 10,000 per day and Rs 20,000 per week. This limit will be increased in the coming days.
# No restrictions of any kind on non-cash payments by cheques, demand drafts, debit or credit cards and electronic fund transfers.
# Rs 500 and Rs 1000 will cease to be legal tender from the midnight of November 8, 2016.
# ATM withdrawals will be restricted to Rs 2,000 per day till November 11, after which this limit may be increased slowly.
# For 72 hours, these places and institutions will continue to accept Rs 500 and Rs 1000 notes for payment:
--Government hospitals will continue to accept old Rs 500, Rs 1000 notes for payment.
--Railway ticket booking counters, ticket counters of government buses and airline ticket counters at airports will accept old notes for purchase of tickets.
--Petrol, diesel and gas stations authorised by public sector oil companies
--Consumer co-operative stores authorised by state or central government.
--Milk booths authorised by state governments
--Crematoria and burial grounds

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur advises the Kgp public to be on a safe side in the next two days and exchange/deposit such notes as soon as possible.
For further details see: http://www.thehindu.com/n...

मीडिया' को लोकतंत्र का चौथा स्तम्भ माना जाता रहा है, और माना भी क्यों न जाए? जब सवाल नहीं पूछे जाएँगे तो फिर बिगड़ते काम काज को सुधारने की आवाज़ कौन उठाएगा या जब चीज़ें सही हो रही होंगी तो उसकी प्रशंसा कर उसे लोगो तक कौन पहुँचाएगा?

कहते हैं विचारों को आप मार नहीं सकते; सही ही है| साथ ही जब तक मीडिया और पत्रकारिता का अस्तित्व बचा रहेगा तब तक ये विचार द्रुत गति से फैलते रहेंगे | आज हम ऐसे समय में जी रहे हैं जब वैचारिक असहिष्णुता आम हो गयी है और ऐसे में ज़रूरत होती है एक जागरूक, बेचैन और साहसी तबके की जो हर किस्म की नाइंसाफियों पर बेबाकी से बोले और समाज के हित में पहलुओं का विश्लेषण करे |

आज से दस वर्ष पूर्व खड़गपुर में जब ऐसे तबके की ज़रूरत महसूस हुई तब स्थापना की गयी उत्साह से लबरेज एक टीम की - 'आवाज़', जिसका उद्देश्य था कि वह कैंपस के जन जन की आवाज़ बन जाए | पत्रकारिता में विचारों की जंग होती ही रहती है; पत्रकार का काम ही है कि वो हर पहलू को दिखाए, और इन दस सालों में न जाने हमने कितने महत्त्वपूर्ण पड़ावों को पार किया, न जाने कितनी मुश्किलें झेलीं और आलोचनाएं तो समय समय पर लगी ही रहती हैं |

खैर, आलोचनाएं इस बात का प्रतीक हैं कि हमें ग़म्भीरता से लिया तो जा रहा है, और इनसे प्रेरित होकर हम लगे रहे, और इतिहास इस बात का साक्षी रहा है कि हमने सूरत को बदलने की कोई कसर न छोड़ी | साल दर साल बीतते गए, पर अपने KGP जनता के हित में हमने हरसम्भव मदद करने की कोशिश की | GC से लेकर प्लेसमेंट्स तक- हर खबर का हर पहलू आप तक पहुँचाया गया |

हम वैसे समय में हैं जहाँ पत्रकारिता में हाथ घुमाकर अपनी ही पीठ थपथपाने का प्रचलन बढ़ गया है क्योंकि जनमानस का उत्साहवर्धन क्षीण पड़ता जा रहा है, और हमें गर्व है हमारी टीम पर, टीम के भूतपूर्व सदस्यों पर, टीम को सतत मार्गदर्शन देने वाले शिक्षकों पर और सबसे बढ़कर आप पर, क्योंकि आप ही से तो हमारा वजूद है | हम सभी एक बार पुनः आप सभी जनों का आभार प्रकट करते हैं और आशा करते हैं कि आगे भी यह सहयोग बना रहेगा |

Continuing the series “आप की राय”,the results of the second poll stress on the communication gap between general student community and office bearers of gymkhana.It can be seen that majority of students demand a platform to raise their problems whereas more than one-fifth felt that officials act carelessly.
Around 31% believed that it should be the responsibility of media houses to organize open house sessions with office bearers where student community could raise their interests.On the other hand,only 10% felt that office bearers are easily approachable and they behave positively.A meager 6.3% say that officials reply to their emails, calls, and messages in case of serious issues.
It is evident from the results that student community is not satisfied with the existing system and the need of the hour is to take up this issue seriously and come up with some feasible solutions.

Carbon dioxide which may be a dangerous waste for the planet is a vital input for Tuticorin Alkali Chemicals for making soda ash. They are unable to get enough carbon dioxide which has been resolved by a six-year-old startup, Carbon Clean Solutions which was set up by two undergraduate students in 2009. The startup meant at  extracting carbon dioxide from flue gases in power plants and use it to make valuable products and even the CEO of Carbon Cleans Solutions said: “We are innovating the carbon dioxide capture so that its price is no more a constraint for conversion to products.” There are about 22 plants which have the capacity to capture around 40million tonnes per year, according to Global CSS Institute, an International member driven organisation. Aniruddha Sharma and Prateek Bumb started this startup and because of their hard work, they are able to develop proprietary solvent which could dissolve carbon dioxide and after testing, it came out that it could remove 90% carbon dioxide from fuel gases. Finally, they got Tuticorin Alkali Chemicals as their customer which is a big breakthrough for the company.

IITs are looking forward to better placements this December as compared to last year in the same month. There has been an increase of about 25%-30% in the pre-placement offers (PPOs) and the companies are eager to sign up to recruit the students. The companies that had already hired students as interns have taken the PPO route this year and are ready to recruit them full time.
Across IITs, IIT-Kharagpur has received 150 PPOs and is inching closer to its last year's mark of 170. The institute is expecting 250 companies to arrive on campus for recruitment, which begins from December 1st. Around 1,950 students are gearing up for the placement process.
Source:- Business Insider

IIT Kharagpur as an institution was founded in August 1951. That makes this years’ batch its 66th batch of freshers. Now that’s a long legacy to be responsible for. To prepare them better for what’s coming and help them maximize what they take away from this place, it is important to identify the patterns where previous batches usually go wrong. As a first step towards getting there, The Scholars’ Avenue spoke to Prof. Sudarsan Neogi from the department of Chemical Engineering for his insights into the same. He had a lot to say from his experience, combining both a student’s and a professor’s perspectives, and here is what we think everyone should know. This is especially a must read for the freshmen who would love to not be influenced by the so-called ‘funda’ that in the first year it’s fine to drown yourself in various activities while your academics slowly fade into the dark.

http://www.scholarsavenue...

World Happiness Report published by the United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network ranks India 118th position among 156 countries in the measure of happiness. The Report reveals a significant decrease in the level of happiness of South Asian countries. Unhappiness and stress might lead to depression and anxiety, and the cases of the same could be found in the very own campus of IIT Kharagpur. World Happiness Report, 2013 demonstrates that a large amount of cases of depression and anxiety disorders occur between the age groups of 15 and 24 years. Hence, being an institute of national importance, IIT Kharagpur can play a major role in improving the current scenario and to promote science and practice of positivity for fostering meaningful life. In a belief of exploring the science behind happiness, IIT Kharagpur Alumnus, Mr. Satinder Singh Rekhi along with Director, IIT Kharagpur, Prof Partha Pratim Chakraborty brought the idea of a new course on ‘The Science of Happiness’ and planned to involve the course in academic curricula of IIT Kharagpur. So, here is the full article on "Science of Happiness" to let the world know more about the science behind happiness and the new initiative of IIT Kharagpur.
http://bit.ly/awaaziitkgp...

Computer Science and Engineering department of our institute in collaboration with Research, Designs and Standards Organisation (RDSO) and Service Improvement Group (SIG) of the Indian Railways has developed a tool suite for electronic railway interlocking system which prevents trains from colliding into each other. Researchers said that this project can be extended for further study to develop traffic operation plans. The Indian Railways, through RDSO, has awarded 12 research projects to IIT Kharagpur’s Centre for Railway Research and several of these project and technologies are being field tested after lab testing at IIT Kharagpur.

Illumination: The Light in Kgp's Night
As the entire nation is gearing up for one of the most awaited festive moments of the year ‘Diwali’, the students at IIT KGP are pouring their heart out for the preparation of their own unique way of celebrating Diwali, the tradition which they call ‘Illumination’ or just ‘Illu’. For KGP, Illu is Diwali and Diwali is Illu. For the freshers who will be going to witness this trademark celebration of Diwali for the first time, they must be feeling intrigued when they find the air buzzing with ‘illu’. They must be having such questions in their mind like what is it?, what’s so special about it?, what for our seniors are working so hard?, is that effort worth it? And all”. As the campus media body of IIT KGP, Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur feels that the tale of this unique tradition must be passed on to the newcomers. So, here is this article on Illumination to let the world know about this masterpiece of KGP students where technology meets tradition.

"The greatest threat to our planet is the belief that someone else will save it"
Well, someone really took that seriously and is an inspiration to us all. At a mere age of 8 when most of us don’t even realize the miracle which we are walking on, a student of Eicher School Faridabad became conscious about the environmental crisis we are facing. The name of this young genius is Madhav Datt. He joined the environmental club in his school in standard 3. Some may find it hard to digest but yes, it was at this very early age where he became aware of the "actions" that are being taken to protect the environment. This notion got into this young mind, and with zeal and passion for changing the world and make Earth a better place. Read the Full article at http://bit.ly/jewelsofkgp...

This year, they received a really positive response to this Sales-drive from all the students of IIT, in this way you all have contributed ‘A Smile’ to an innocent face.

The Scholars' Avenue recently got the opportunity to interview Prof Priyadarshini Patnaik, HOD of Department of Humanities and Social Sciences and Coordinator at Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness. We sat down with him to discuss the initiatives taken by the center and how beneficial it is for the student community.

The Center has recently been catapulted into the public view with its highly publicized workshop on happiness which saw participation from eminent personality, most notably Ms. Sonja Lyubomirsky, the author of How of Happiness and R. Gopalakrishnan, the former director of TATA Sons Ltd. The workshop is among the first of many initiatives taken by the center. For now , the center aims at focusing on the first year students and the final years who face a great deal of stress while adjusting to the new environment and coping up with the pressure of placements respectively. They have collaborated with Gymkhana and CDC and are planning on conducting various kinds of workshops for this purpose.

Elaborating on the course structure Professor Patnaik explained it to be a short one, over a period of two weeks, and through 10 hours of lectures and about 5 hours of interaction and activities, which will attempt to (a) understand happiness scientifically, and (b) develop a hands-on experience by exploring its various components through introspection, experience, psychometric measures, physiological measures and other scientific tools. He even talked about a survey that was conducted amongst the UG and PG students. The findings of this survey indicated a huge gap between what the students want to do and what they actually end up doing. They realized that this could be the starting point of all the unhappiness amongst the students. A lot of alumni have been included in the project to share their experience. According to them, work life balance is very essential. Extra curricular activities, where people are not evaluated play an important role in having a balanced life. Which is why they even had the science of happiness challenge. Three projects on community service were selected. Two were student groups and the other was a community group .Each got RS.30,000 to do something in the next few months and bring about a change in the IIT community. The center is looking forward to doing it every year and has also planned on roping in CSR and corporate health resources to get a pool of more money.
Next semester they are planning on a couple of electives. "The goal of the director as well as Mr. Rekhi is that by 2017 autumn semester we have a micro -specialization of The science of happiness .So we are targeting that by July 2017 we will have an array of courses, on its different components like positive psychology, self- introspection, resilience and character building . " said Professor Patnaik. On being asked about the career opportunities that the students will be exposed to after taking up the course he said , "We have many students who after going out will start exploring will switch and move into another area or will start integrating the two. Career opportunities and impact of the courses will be in two different ways. First one is that implementation of these in various kinds of organizational and administrative positions. And the other one would be that we could, later on use this micro- specialization to explore further and study deeper into the area."
He also commented on the previous attempts made to quantify happiness regarding which he said, “There are a few tools which may use certain parameters to quantify happiness. These can be tricky and will have to be used with caution. If somebody sees that my happiness index shows that I am unhappy, and that kind of sets the entire ball rolling and that is not how it should be and that is now how it is. That would be against the ground rules set for the course. But in the end , I would like to say these are only subjective indicators . We definitely use a lot of statistics for these indicators. “
They have also planned to expand the outreach of the center and have already been approached by the psychiatrists at Tata Medical who were very keen on discussing the increasing stress levels among students.

The registration for this course has already begun. It is a one credit course and will run from 1st to 12th November this semester. Eminent Prof. of Psychology, Prof. Manas K. Mandal will lead the team of faculty who will offer this course. Interested participants may visit ERP in order to register:
Academic -- Students -- Micro Credit Registration (choose the course: Introduction to the Science of Happiness)

The course can take a maximum of 100 students on the basis of pre-registration and interest. Registration will close on 27th October. For further details students can visit their site :
http://www.happiness-iitk... /

message:
Researchers from our institute have achieved another milestone in their field. They have designed a software that enables those with neuro-motor disorders to access the web, play games, and participate in social networking with ease. This disease occurs when specialist nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord called motor neurons stop working properly and eventually lead to muscle weakness, often with visible wasting.
"For the neuro-motor disorders, we have developed the interface by which they can access web and carry out social networking activities," says Professor Anupam Basu, from the department of computer science , lead researcher and Head and Chairman, Centre for Education Technology, IIT Kharagpur.

Extending its brilliant heritage in biotechnical research, IIT Kharagpur,jointly with IIEST Shibpur and Guru Nanak Institute of Dental Sciences and Research (GNIDSR), has initiated a joint interdisciplinary research in fields of oral health care by signing a MoU on the same. This initiative aims to gather information and tackle oral cancer and pre-cancer problems the people in India face.
Already into lines of conducting stem cell research,which would range cures for many ailments, the Institute has therefore extended its arms wide for future biotechnical research in India and the world at large.
Such an initiative wouldn't only benefit the general public,but would also open doors to advanced stem cell and other research avenues in the near future.

The revamped and refurbished Kabaddi World Cup had a grand finale in Ahmedabad on Saturday night, after a thrilling final that saw hosts India produce top class kabaddi to overcome Iran 38-29. However, some things never change, and India's kabaddi supremacy is certainly one of these. Indian Side considered overwhelming favorites to lift their third World Cup, did so in emphatic fashion. However, doing so against an Iran side that played the match of their lifetimes has an astonishing feel about it.

Awaaz IIT Kharagpur hereby celebrate this victory of our country in Kabaddi World Cup 2016.

With the utmost pain and sadness, we are informing you that Sagar Khurana (CSE/2013/Patel) is no more between us. He was diagnosed with cancer and pneumonia which led to his sad demise yesterday in Gurgaon. Sagar was a great human being of selfless nature who was always very humble in every situation that he faced. He represented Patel Hall and IIT Kharagpur in Cricket and was one of the best fast bowlers KGP has ever produced. He held a number of posts in his hall during his stay at IIT Kharagpur and was a well known Maths wiz and a tech geek in the campus. He was one of brightest students of the 2013 CSE batch who never refrained himself in helping out people. He was a guiding light, a star to whoever knew him and the reason why so many people are crying today is because above all things, he was the sweetest soul you'll come across. A heart so generous, a soul so pure and an attitude that's par excellence. We weep today because we have lost someone who was in all of us. KGP will always remember him as its sincerest and brightest student. May his soul rest in peace.

To express its deep condolences, Patel Hall is organizing a candle march today at 6 PM from PATEL HALL via Gymkhana TO BIDHAN CHOWK in the main building. We request the entire student fraternity and faculty to attend this candle march.

Are the rising numbers of mosquitoes in our campus bothering you? Well, we should be happy that institute is all prepared to help you in case you catch malaria. Researchers at Bio-medical Imaging Informatics (BMI) Lab, led by Chandan Chakraborty and his research team at the School of Medical Science & Technology, IIT Kharagpur  has developed a smartphone app that will be beneficial in the detection of malaria. The present detection and treatment methods are very time-consuming. The development of such an app and technology can help in easy and early detection of malaria. The app has been tested on more than 200 microscopic images of 80 patients and it detected the disease with more than 90%  accuracy.
